Tetris: Designed by Alexey Pajitnov, a russian who lived during 1984
The name for the game is derived from a greek numerical prefix
The objective is to manipulate blocks to create complete horizontal lines
Initially programed for the Electronika 60 computer, a Soviet computer system
Gained widespread popularity when it was released on a handheld console
Became one of the  most successful and recognizable video games of all time in 1989
Known for its addictive game play and simple yet challenging mechanics
Accessible to players of all ages
Released on numerous platforms
Ported to 65 different platforms
Sold over 200 million copies worldwide
Has been recognized for its impact on popular culture
In the game, the speed of the blocks falling become faster and faster as the rounds progress
Features a scoring system based on the number of lines cleared
Praised for its intuitive game play and its ability to engage players
It has a iconic theme song,it's a Russian folk tune called 'Korobeiniki'
It has various tournaments and competitions that have been held worldwide, attracting skilled players who compete for high scores and prizes
Inspired numerous puzzle games and has had a significant influence on the puzzle game genre as a whole
The creator has has continued to develop and contribute to the gaming industry

Satisfactory: A first-person open-world building game developed and published by same game studio
Released in early access on the Epic Games Store in March 2019
In game, players take on the role of of someone who crash-landed on a planet and must construct and automate massive industrial complexes to survive and thrive
Combines elements of exploration, resource gathering, factory building, and automation to create a complex and immersive game play experience
Features a large and diverse world with different biomes, creatures, and resources to discover and exploit
Players can construct a wide variety of structures
Offers a scalable multiplayer mode, allowing players to collaborate with friends in building and expanding
Employs a tiered progression system,where players unlock new technologies and buildings as they progress
Has two game modes, but requires a bit of config magic to get the other game mode
Provides a rich and detailed world, with stunning graphics, realistic physics, and immersive sound design
Encourages exploration and rewards players for venturing into uncharted territories
Players must manage their power supply and distribution effectively
Supports modding, allowing players to customize and enhance their game play experience with user-created modifications
Offers a dynamic day-night cycle, with different challenges and opportunities presented during both periods
Map is generated procedurally, ensuring that each play through offers a unique and unpredictable experience
Received regular updates and content additions since its release, including new biomes, buildings, vehicles, and game play features
Has an active and passionate community, with players sharing their creations, strategies, and mods on various platforms and forums
Praised for its immersive game play, satisfying progression, and the sense of accomplishment that comes from building and expanding intricate industrial complexes
The developers of this game, are known for a previous hit of a rather 'goaty' theme

TF2: Is a team-based first-person shooter game developed and published by VALVe Corporation
Released as part of The Orange Box bundle in October 2007 for Windows, Xbox 360, and PlayStation 3
Is the sequel to the original mod for Quake, developed by a software team named after the mod in the late 1990s
Features two opposing teams, RED (Reliable Excavation & Demolition) and BLU (Builders League United), competing in various game modes
Known for its distinct art style, combining cartoonish visuals with exaggerated character designs and humor
Called 'A hat simulator war game'
Offers nine unique character classes, each with their own distinct abilities, weapons, and play styles
Features a variety of game modes
Has a strong emphasis on teamwork and class-based coordination, with each class playing a specific role in the team composition
Introduced the concept of 'hats' as cosmetic items that players can earn or purchase to customize their characters' appearance
Features an in-game economy where players can trade items, hats, and weapons with each other
Originally had a paid model but became free-to-play in June 2011, with revenue generated from in-game purchases and the sale of cosmetic items
Has a vibrant and active community, with a dedicated player base and competitive scene
Hasn't had a major update for many days
Inspired various fan-made creations, such as artwork, videos, and custom game modes
Held several in-game events
Has a iconic theme song included with it's iconic soundtrack album
Has a thriving competitive scene, with tournaments and leagues organized by both community groups and VALVe
A unique style of humor and storytelling, often using comedic dialogue and character interactions
Despite its age,Have an active player base and receives occasional small updates from Valve

Widely regarded as one of the most influential and critically acclaimed video games of all time, helping to popularize the platforming genre
Main objective in most games is to rescue a princess

Introduced many memorable characters
Known for their colorful and imaginative worlds, featuring diverse themes such as grasslands, underwater levels, desert environments, and even outer space
Power-ups are a significant element of the games
Has sold over 380 million copies worldwide, making it one of the best-selling video game franchises of all time
Feature hidden secrets,hidden blocks, and alternate paths, encouraging exploration and replay ability
Franchise has expanded beyond video games, with merchandise,an animated television series, and a critically acclaimed animated movie,in 2023
Franchise has received numerous awards and accolades, including induction into the World Video Game Hall of Fame in 2015
Continues to be a beloved and enduring franchise, with new installments and remakes released regularly, captivating new generations of players

Chess: One of the oldest known board games, with its origins dating back over 1,500 years
Evolved from its predecessor, the Indian game of chaturanga
The objective is to capture the opponent's most valued piece, putting it in a position where it is under attack and cannot escape capture
Played on an 8x8 grid of alternating light and dark squares like a checkerboard
Player starts with 16 pieces
The capture of the most valued piece will end the game
The most powerful piece,capable of moving in any direction along ranks, files, and diagonals
A game of strategy and tactics, with players using their pieces to control the board, attack the opponent's pieces, and defend their own
Played worldwide and is considered a sport, recognized by the International Olympic Committee
Often referred to as the 'game of kings' due to its historical association with nobility and intellectual prowess
Governed by a set of rules ,established by the FIDE
Rich competitive scene, with players participating in tournaments at various levels, from local club events to world championship matches
Used as a tool for education, as it promotes critical thinking, problem-solving skills, concentration, and strategic planning
First machines that play the game were developed in the 18th century
Has a wide variety of tactical patterns and strategies, such as forks, pins, discovered attacks, and sacrifices
Time control is often regulated in the game by using clocks, which allocate a specific amount of time to each player
As a sport for the mind, as it requires mental discipline, calculation, pattern recognition, and positional understanding
Game that transcends language and cultural barriers, allowing players from different backgrounds to compete and communicate through the universal language of the game
this game is very portable
Has been ported online
Monopoly: A board game that was first published by Parker Brothers in 1935
Originally based on an earlier game called 'The Landlord's Game' created by Elizabeth Magie in the early 20th century
The objective is to become the wealthiest player by buying, renting, and trading properties
A square board featuring a stylized cityscape, divided into spaces representing properties, utilities, and various other elements
Players move around the board using dice rolls, and they can buy properties they land on, build houses and hotels, and collect rent from other players
Features a set of distinctive playing pieces, including the classic ones such as the top hat, dog, car, battleship, and thimble
Properties based on real-life locations
Over the years, it has been localized to many countries, featuring local city names and landmarks to reflect different regions
Incorporates elements of luck and strategy
Become a cultural phenomenon, with various themed editions featuring popular brands, movies, TV shows, and cities
Been translated into more than 47 languages and sold in over 114 countries, making it one of the most widely played board games worldwide
Various rules and strategies that have evolved over time, and it has a dedicated community of competitive players who participate in tournaments
Longest game played continuously is over 70 days
Praise and criticism over the years, with some commending its game play and educational value, while others have criticized it for promoting capitalism and greed
Been adapted into digital versions, allowing players to play online or on video game consoles
Original design of the board features three corner spaces
Spawned numerous spin-offs and variations, including card games, video games, and themed editions with unique rules and components
Licensed by Hasbro, which acquired Parker Brothers in 1991
Inducted into the National Toy Hall of Fame and has been recognized as one of the most influential board games of all time
Continues to be popular among players of all ages, providing entertainment and social interaction for families and friends
Cards against Humanity: A party game that was first released in 2011 by a group of Highland Park High School alumni
Created through a successful Kick starter campaign and gained popularity for its dark humor and irreverent content
Played with a deck of black cards, which contain prompts or statements, and a deck of white cards, which contain responses or fill-in-the-blanks
Highly interactive and encourages players to create humorous and often inappropriate combinations of cards
Intended for mature audiences due to its explicit and offensive content
The game's tagline is 'A party game for horrible people.'
Been praised for its ability to generate laughter, encourage creativity, and break social barriers
Creators of the game have emphasized the importance of not taking the content seriously and viewing it as satire
Spawned numerous expansion packs, adding new cards and themes to the game
Has a 'house rules' variant, allowing players to modify the official rules to suit their preferences or add their own custom cards
Released special holiday-themed packs
Creators of the game have used their success to support various charitable causes, including donating funds to organizations and scholarships
Received both praise and criticism for its controversial and provocative content
Become a popular choice for parties, gatherings, and game nights, with its easy-to-learn rules and fast-paced game play
Online versions of the game that allow players to enjoy the game remotely or with friends who are not physically present
Encourages players to embrace their creativity, think outside the box, and explore dark and taboo subjects in a humorous context
Won multiple awards, including the Golden Geek Award for Best Party Game and the Toy of the Year Award
Inspired similar games with a similar concept but different themes and variations
The creators of the game have engaged in unconventional marketing tactics, such as purchasing a private island and offering shares to their customers
Gained a cult following and has become a cultural phenomenon, often referenced in popular media and social gatherings
Dungeon and Dragons: A tabletop role-playing game (RPG) originally designed by Gary Gygax and Dave Arneson and first published in 1974 by TSR, Inc
Often credited with being the first modern role-playing game, serving as the foundation for the entire RPG genre
Set in a fantasy world where players create fictional characters
Known for its flexibility and open-ended nature, allowing players to explore vast worlds
Played using rule books that outline the mechanics and guidelines for aspects of the game
Polyhedral dice set, including various-sided dice, to determine the outcomes of actions and events
Offers a wide variety of characters,allowing players to create unique and diverse characters with different abilities and skills
Encourages cooperative play and teamwork, with players working together to overcome challenges and achieve their goals
Adventures can range from simple dungeon crawls to epic quests
Renowned for its rich storytelling and immersive worlds
Had multiple editions over the years, with each edition introducing new rules, mechanics, and updates to the game system
The release of it's 3rd edition in 2000 marked a significant shift, introducing a more streamlined and accessible rule set
Vibrant community of players and enthusiasts, who often gather to play at game stores, conventions, and online platforms
Influenced by its portrayal in popular culture, including movies, TV shows, and references in other games and literature
Multitude of video games, both official adaptations and games that draw inspiration from its mechanics and fantasy setting
Endless possibilities for storytelling and character development, allowing players to create memorable and dynamic narratives
Has a vast array of supplemental materials
